qas.question: Name a reason to take a database backward in time?
Is each database backup kept in the same file?
Who can restore a database that has been corrupted?
What parameter is requiret to restore a database?

plausible_answers.text: database is found corrupted due to a software error

qas.question: What is not a reason to take a database backward in time?
What type of file has no dedicated ones involved?
Who can restore a database that has been deleted?
What can't be restored to a previous date?
What operation can be done only once per year?

context: Sometimes it is desired to bring <b7_0>a database<b7_0/> back to a previous state (for many reasons, e.g., cases when the <a0_0><b4_0>database is found corrupted<a0_0/> due to a software error<b4_0/>, or if it has been updated with erroneous data). To achieve this a <b8_0>backup operation<b8_0/> is done occasionally or continuously, where each desired database state (i.e., the values of its data and their embedding in database's data structures) is kept within <a1_0>dedicated <b5_0>backup files<b5_0/><a1_0/> (many techniques exist to do this effectively). When this state is needed, i.e., when it is decided by a <a2_0><b6_0>database administrator<b6_0/><a2_0/> to bring the database back to this state (e.g., by specifying this state by a <a3_0>desired point in time<a3_0/> when the database was in this state), these files are utilized to restore that state.
